intro: Gilia virgata var. ambigua, commonly known as the ambiguous gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from pink to purple, typically blooming in summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. Its morphology includes hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, making it a distinctive yet adaptable species.
